pl.mareklangiewicz.myblog.coroutines

Class A_Coroutines_Intro

  • pl.mareklangiewicz.myblog.coroutines.A_Coroutines_Intro

  • public class A_Coroutines_Intro

    Kotlin Coroutines Intro in "TDD" (kind of..)

    This is my attempt to learn about kotlin coroutines and write some tests on the way.

    The content here is based on Coroutines Guide but here it is both: documentation and runnable code in one place.

    See Also:
    Coroutines Guide

      • A_Coroutines_Intro

        public A_Coroutines_Intro()

        Kotlin Coroutines Intro in "TDD" (kind of..)

        This is my attempt to learn about kotlin coroutines and write some tests on the way.

        The content here is based on Coroutines Guide but here it is both: documentation and runnable code in one place.

        See Also:
        Coroutines Guide

      • A_basics

        public void A_basics()

        First coroutine

        launch(CommonPool) {
    delay(1000L)
    "World!".p
}
"Hello,".p
Thread.sleep(2000L)

      • B_runBlocking

        public void B_runBlocking()

        Bridging blocking and nonblocking worlds

        runBlocking {
    delay(1000)
    "1000".p
    delay(1000)
    "2000".p
    delay(1000)
    "3000".p
}

      • D_introduceJob

        public void D_introduceJob()

        Use Job class to handle coroutine state and to wait (non blocking) for it to finish

        sample {
        val job = launch(CommonPool) {
            delay(1000L)
            "World!".p
        }
        "Hello,".p
        job.join() // this suspending function (join) waits for job to finish
    }

        public void E_extractSuspendingFunction()

        Extract suspending function

        sample {
        val job = launch(CommonPool) {
            delayAndPrintWorld()
        }
        "Hello,".p
        job.join() // this suspending function (join) waits for job to finish
    }

      • E_coroutineIsSequential

        public void E_coroutineIsSequential()

        Suspending functions are called sequentially

        sample {
        "start".p
        val result = delayAndReturn7() + delayAndReturn8()
        "end result: $result.".p // it will take two seconds to print it
    }

      • E_coroutineParallel

        public void E_coroutineParallel()

        Run suspending functions in parallel

        sample {
        "start".p
        val a1 = async(context) { delayAndReturn7() } // we do NOT await for it yet (but it already starts the `delayAndReturn7`)
        val a2 = async(context) { delayAndReturn8() } // we do NOT await for it yet (but it already starts the `delayAndReturn8`)
        val result = a1.await() + a2.await()
        "end result: $result.".p // it will take ONE second to print it
    }

      • E_lazyAsync

        public void E_lazyAsync()

        Run suspending functions in parallel, but lazily

        sample {
        "start".p
        val a1 = async(context, CoroutineStart.LAZY) { delayAndReturn7() }
        val a2 = async(context, CoroutineStart.LAZY) { delayAndReturn8() }
        val result = a1.await() + a2.await()
        "end result: $result.".p // it will take TWO second to print it
    }

      • F_coroutinesAreLightweight

        public void F_coroutinesAreLightweight()

        Run 100 000 coroutines in parallel

        Coroutines are extremely lightweight so we can start A LOT of them

        sample {
        val jobs = List(100_000) {
            // create a lot of coroutines and list their jobs
            launch(CommonPool) {
                delay(1000L)
                print(".")
            }
        }
        jobs.forEach { it.join() } // wait for all jobs to complete
    }

      • G_exitWhileCoroutineStillActive

        public void G_exitWhileCoroutineStillActive()

        Active coroutines are terminated when the whole process ends (like daemon threads)

        sample {
        launch(CommonPool) {
            repeat(1000) { i ->
                "I'm sleeping $i ...".p
                delay(500L)
            }
        }
        delay(1300L) // just quit after delay
    }

      • H_cancelJobCorrectly

        public void H_cancelJobCorrectly()

        Cancel coroutine with Job.cancel

        sample {
        val job = launch(CommonPool) {
            repeat(1000) { i ->
                "I'm sleeping $i ...".p
                delay(500L)
            }
        }
        delay(1300L) // delay a bit
        "main: I'm tired of waiting!".p
        job.cancel() // cancels the job
        delay(1300L) // delay a bit to ensure it was cancelled indeed
        "main: Now I can quit.".p
    }

      • I_cancellationIsCooperative_1

        public void I_cancellationIsCooperative_1()

        Cancellation is cooperative 1

        This example shows that we can not cancel coroutine that doesn't listen

        sample {
        val job = launch(CommonPool) {
            var nextPrintTime = 0L
            var i = 0
            while (i < 10) { // computation loop
                val currentTime = System.currentTimeMillis()
                if (currentTime >= nextPrintTime) {
                    "I'm sleeping ${i++} ...".p
                    nextPrintTime = currentTime + 500L
                }
            }
        }
        delay(1300L) // delay a bit
        "main: I'm tired of waiting!".p
        job.cancel() // cancels the job
        delay(1300L) // delay a bit to see if it was cancelled....
        "main: Now I can quit.".p
    }

      • I_cancellationIsCooperative_2

        public void I_cancellationIsCooperative_2()

        Cancellation is cooperative 2

        This example shows that we can cancel coroutine using isActive property from CoroutineScope

        sample {
        val job = launch(CommonPool) {
            var nextPrintTime = 0L
            var i = 0
            while (isActive) { // computation loop
                val currentTime = System.currentTimeMillis()
                if (currentTime >= nextPrintTime) {
                    "I'm sleeping ${i++} ...".p
                    nextPrintTime = currentTime + 500L
                }
            }
        }
        delay(1300L) // delay a bit
        "main: I'm tired of waiting!".p
        job.cancel() // cancels the job
        delay(1300L) // delay a bit to see if it was cancelled....
        "main: Now I can quit.".p
    }

      • I_cancellationIsCooperative_3_withTimeout

        public void I_cancellationIsCooperative_3_withTimeout()

        Cancellation with timeout

        This example shows withTimeout function

        sample {
        "main: start.".p
        launch(CommonPool) {
            withTimeout(100) {
                // change to 10000 to see the difference
                var nextPrintTime = 0L
                while (true) { // computation loop
                    yield() // this will throw CancellationException on timeout
                    val currentTime = System.currentTimeMillis()
                    if (currentTime >= nextPrintTime) {
                        "I'm sleeping...".p
                        nextPrintTime = currentTime + 500L
                    }
                }
            }
        }
        delay(3000L) // delay a bit
        "main: end.".p
    }

      • IA_contexts

        public void IA_contexts()

        Different contexts example

        sample {
        "main: start".p
        val jobs = arrayListOf()
        jobs += launch(Unconfined) {
            // not confined -- will work with main thread
            "Unconfined".p
        }
        jobs += launch(context) {
            // context of the parent, runBlocking coroutine
            "context".p
        }
        jobs += launch(CommonPool) {
            // will get dispatched to ForkJoinPool.commonPool (or equivalent)
            "CommonPool".p
        }
        jobs += launch(newSingleThreadContext("MyOwnThread")) {
            // will get its own new thread
            "newSTC".p
        }
        "main: joining all jobs".p
        for (job in jobs)
            job.join()
        "main: end".p
    }

      • IA_contexts_2

        public void IA_contexts_2()

        run and runBlocking with specified context

        "main: start".p
val ctx1 = newSingleThreadContext("Ctx1")
val ctx2 = newSingleThreadContext("Ctx2")
runBlocking(ctx1) {
    "runBlocking(ctx1): start".p
    run(ctx2) {
        "run(ctx2)".p
    }
    "runBlocking(ctx1): end".p
}
"main: end".p

      • J_underTheHood_1

        public void J_underTheHood_1()

        Under the hood test

        val coroutine: suspend Unit.() -> Unit = {
    "coroutine start".p
    delay(1000)
    "coroutine middle".p
    delay(1000)
    "coroutine end".p
}
val completion = object : Continuation {
    override val context = EmptyCoroutineContext
    override fun resume(value: Unit) {
        "completion: completed normally".p
    }
    override fun resumeWithException(exception: Throwable) {
        "completion: exception: $exception".p
    }
}
"main: start".p
coroutine.startCoroutine(Unit, completion)
"main: after startCoroutine".p
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: after sleep 3000".p

      • mydelay

        public java.lang.Object mydelay(long time,
                                Continuation<? super kotlin.Unit> $continuation)

        Simple suspending function implementation

        Important: the "return" keyword (or expression body syntax) is necessary here. Without "return" it returns from suspension more than once.. looks like bug in state machine generation

      • J_underTheHood_2

        public void J_underTheHood_2()

        Under the hood test 2 without using kotlinx stuff

        val coroutine: suspend () -> Unit = {
    "coroutine start".p
    mydelay(1000)
    "coroutine middle".p
    mydelay(1000)
    "coroutine end".p
}
val completion = object : Continuation {
    override val context = EmptyCoroutineContext
    override fun resume(value: Unit) {
        "completion: completed normally".p
    }
    override fun resumeWithException(exception: Throwable) {
        "completion: exception: $exception".p
    }
}
"main: start".p
val continuation = coroutine.createCoroutine(completion)
"main: after createCoroutine".p
continuation.resume(Unit)
"main: after continuation resume (to start coroutine)".p
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: after sleep 3000".p

    "Got continuation: $continuation, but I will never call .resume(Unit)".p
}

        "Got continuation: $continuation, but I will never call .resume(Unit)".p
    }

      • J_underTheHood_3

        public void J_underTheHood_3()

        Under the hood - error case investigation

        This example should never print "coroutine end", but it does immediately...

        val coroutine: suspend () -> Unit = {
    "coroutine start".p
    mynever1() // TO FIX IT: CHANGE "mynever1()" TO "mynever2()"
    "coroutine end - THIS LINE SHOULD NEVER BE CALLED!".p
}
val completion = object : Continuation {
    override val context = EmptyCoroutineContext
    override fun resume(value: Unit) {
        "completion: completed normally".p
    }
    override fun resumeWithException(exception: Throwable) {
        "completion: exception: $exception".p
    }
}
"main: start".p
val continuation = coroutine.createCoroutine(completion)
"main: after createCoroutine".p
continuation.resume(Unit)
"main: after continuation resume (to start coroutine)".p
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: after sleep 3000".p

        public void K_sequence()

        val seq: Sequence = buildSequence {
    //delay(10) // this is forbidden
    yield(2)
    yield(4)
    yield(6)
}
for (i in seq) "$i".p

      • createFuture

        public <T> java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture<T> createFuture(kotlin.jvm.functions.Function1<? super kotlin.coroutines.Continuation<? super T>,? extends java.lang.Object> block)

        Create (and start) a future representing a coroutine

        val future = CompletableFuture()
val completion = object : Continuation {
    override val context = EmptyCoroutineContext
    override fun resume(value: T) {
        future.complete(value)
    }
    override fun resumeWithException(exception: Throwable) {
        future.completeExceptionally(exception)
    }
}
block.startCoroutine(completion)
return future

      • L_completableFuture

        public void L_completableFuture()

        Wrap coroutine in completable future

        "main: start".p
val future: CompletableFuture = createFuture {
    "coroutine: start".p
    delay(1000)
    "coroutine: middle".p
    delay(1000)
    "coroutine: end".p
    666
}
"main: before: thenAccept".p
future
        .thenApply { it * 10 }
        .thenAccept { "thenAccept: $it".p }
"main: after: thenAccept".p
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: after: sleep".p

      • prepareFuture

        public <T> kotlin.jvm.functions.Function0<java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture> prepareFuture(kotlin.jvm.functions.Function1<? super kotlin.coroutines.Continuation<? super T>,? extends java.lang.Object> block)

        Prepare a future representing a coroutine

        val future = CompletableFuture()
val completion = object : Continuation {
    override val context = EmptyCoroutineContext
    override fun resume(value: T) {
        future.complete(value)
    }
    override fun resumeWithException(exception: Throwable) {
        future.completeExceptionally(exception)
    }
}
val continuation = block.createCoroutine(completion)
return {
    continuation.resume(Unit)
    future
}

      • L_completableFuture_2

        public void L_completableFuture_2()

        Wrap coroutine in LAZY completable future

        "main: start".p
val futureCreator: () -> CompletableFuture = prepareFuture {
    "coroutine: start".p
    delay(1000)
    "coroutine: middle".p
    delay(1000)
    "coroutine: end".p
    666
}
"main: after prepareFuture".p
val future = futureCreator()
"main: before: thenAccept".p
future
        .thenApply { it * 10 }
        .thenAccept { "thenAccept: $it".p }
"main: after: thenAccept".p
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: after: sleep".p

      • suspend

        public <T> java.lang.Object suspend(java.util.concurrent.CompletableFuture<T> $receiver,
                                    Continuation<? super T> $continuation)

        Wrap future in suspension point

        suspendCoroutine { continuation ->
        thenAccept { continuation.resume(it) }
    }

      • L_completableFuture_3

        public void L_completableFuture_3()

        Wrap futures in suspension points

        val scheduler = Executors.newSingleThreadScheduledExecutor()
val myDelayFuture: (time: Long) -> CompletableFuture = { time ->
    val future = CompletableFuture()
    scheduler.schedule({ future.complete(Unit) }, time, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
    future
}
"main: start".p
launch(CommonPool) {
    "coroutine start".p
    myDelayFuture(1000).suspend()
    "coroutine middle".p
    myDelayFuture(1000).suspend()
    "coroutine end".p
}
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: after: sleep".p

      • L_completableFuture_4

        public void L_completableFuture_4()

        Use future related functions from kotlinx.coroutines

        Important: both futures are started immediately

        "main: start".p
future {
    "main future: start".p
    val f1 = future {
        "f1: start".p
        delay(1000) // sleep 1s
        "f1: end".p
        1
    }
    val f2 = future {
        "f2: start".p
        delay(1000) // sleep 1s
        "f2: end".p
        2
    }
    "main future: before awaits".p
    val f1val = f1.await()
    "main future: after f1.await(): f1val = $f1val".p
    val f2val = f2.await()
    "main future: after f2.await(): f2val = $f2val".p
    val sum = f1val + f2val
    "main future: after awaits: sum = $sum".p
}
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: end".p

      • L_completableFuture_5

        public void L_completableFuture_5()

        Use prepareFuture to make last example more lazy and simple

        Now we pause two times when waiting for f1 and then for f2

        "main: start".p
future {
    "main future: start".p
    val f1 = prepareFuture {
        "f1: start".p
        delay(1000) // sleep 1s
        "f1: end".p
        1
    }
    val f2 = prepareFuture {
        "f2: start".p
        delay(1000) // sleep 1s
        "f2: end".p
        2
    }
    "main future: before awaits".p
    val f1val = f1().await()
    "main future: after f1.await(): f1val = $f1val".p
    val f2val = f2().await()
    "main future: after f2.await(): f2val = $f2val".p
    val sum = f1val + f2val
    "main future: after awaits: sum = $sum".p
}
Thread.sleep(3000)
"main: end".p

      • M_rxSubscriber

        public void M_rxSubscriber()

        Implement rx subscriber wrapping coroutine block

                val flowable = Flowable
                .interval(300, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS)
                .take(10)
        val subscriber = RxSubscriber {
            receive().p
//            close()
            receive().p
            receive().p
//            delay(1500)
            receive().p
            receive().p
            receive().p
        }
        flowable.subscribe(subscriber)
        Thread.sleep(10000)

      • fibonacci

        public java.lang.Object fibonacci(int n,
                                  kotlinx.coroutines.experimental.channels.SendChannel<? super java.lang.Integer> c,
                                  Continuation<? super kotlin.Unit> $continuation)

        Fibonacci numbers generator

        Sends given number of Fibonacci numbers to given SendChannel

      • N_fibonacciChannels

        public void N_fibonacciChannels()

        Use channels to implement fibonacci numbers generator

        val c = Channel(2) // experiment with different capacity
launch(CommonPool) {
    fibonacci(10, c)
}
launch(CommonPool) {
    for (x in c) {
        delay(300)
        "*********************** received $x".p
    }
}
Thread.sleep(3000)

      • O_produceChannel

        public void O_produceChannel()

        Use produce utility function

        "main: start".p
val channel = produce(CommonPool) {
    for (i in 1..10) {
        "produce: sending: $i".p
        send(i)
    }
}
launch(CommonPool) {
    for (i in channel)
        "received: $i".p
}
Thread.sleep(2000)
"main: end".p

        Simple filter implementation for channels

      • P_producePrimeNumbers

        public void P_producePrimeNumbers()

        Generate prime numbers with crazy channels pipeline

        sample {
        var cur = produceNumbersFrom(CommonPool, 2)
        for (i in 1..20) {
            val prime = cur.receive()
            "prime: $prime".p
            cur = cur.filter(context) { it % prime != 0 }
        }
    }

        val channel = Channel()
        launch(context) { channel.sendPeriodically("foo200", 200) }
        launch(context) { channel.sendPeriodically("BAR500", 500) }
        for (s in channel.take(context, 6))
            s.p
    }

      • player

        public java.lang.Object player(java.lang.String name,
                               kotlinx.coroutines.experimental.channels.Channel<pl.mareklangiewicz.myblog.coroutines.A_Coroutines_Intro.Ball> table,
                               Continuation<? super kotlin.Unit> $continuation)

        A player in ping pong game

      • R_channelsAreFair

        public void R_channelsAreFair()

        Channels are fair

        sample {
        val table = Channel() // a shared table
        launch(context) { player("ping", table) }
        launch(context) { player("pong", table) }
//        launch(context) { player("PENGGG", table) }
        table.send(Ball(0)) // serve the ball
        delay(2000) // delay 1 second
        table.receive() // game over, grab the ball
    }

      • massiveRun

        public java.lang.Object massiveRun(kotlin.coroutines.experimental.CoroutineContext context,
                                   kotlin.jvm.functions.Function1<? super kotlin.coroutines.Continuation<? super kotlin.Unit>,? extends java.lang.Object> action,
                                   Continuation<? super kotlin.Unit> $continuation)

        Runs given action a million times using thousand coroutines

        val n = 1000 // number of coroutines to launch
val k = 1000 // times an action is repeated by each coroutine
val time = measureTimeMillis {
    val jobs = List(n) {
        launch(context) {
            repeat(k) { action() }
        }
    }
    jobs.forEach { it.join() }
}

      • R_massiveNonsyncAction

        public void R_massiveNonsyncAction()

        Massive non sync action

        sample {
        "start".p
        var counter = 0 // @Volatile would not help much; AtomicInteger would work correctly.
//        val context = newSingleThreadContext("single") // this will increment counter correctly all the times
        val context = newFixedThreadPoolContext(2, "double") // this should cause some sync errors
//        val context = CommonPool // this should cause some sync errors on systems with multiple CPUs (more than 2)
        massiveRun(context) {
            counter ++
        }
        "end. counter: $counter (should be 1000000) (error: ${1000000-counter})".p
    }
